capsules_submitted.utterance: Snape is indeed a male character in the Harry Potter series. I've always found him to be quite an intriguing figure, with his complex and sometimes dark personality. His strict demeanor and sharp tongue can be quite intimidating, but at the same time, he has a certain depth to him that makes him more than just a one-dimensional villain.
capsules_submitted.reply: this is news to me. i've never heard of professor snape before, can you tell me more about him?

capsules_submitted.utterance: Snape is indeed an adult, and I've had my fair share of dealing with him in the Hogwarts years. He's a complex character, to say the least.
capsules_submitted.reply: that makes my day! so, snape is also an adult, just like vernon.

capsules_submitted.utterance: So Harry's lineage is actually quite clear-cut. He comes from a very traditional wizarding family background, with his parents being James and Lily Potter, and his grandparents being Sirius and Petunia Black - all of whom are well-documented in the wizarding world as being part of the pure-blood families.

capsules_submitted.utterance: Ron's lineage is indeed quite impressive. As a wizard myself, I can appreciate the importance of having a strong magical heritage. Ron's pure-blood background has certainly served him well in his battles against the Dark Lord.
